title: Party’s over for Airbnb operators
text:
AirBNB castles .. Scottish Castle - The daffodils at Brodie Castle. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied Airbnb 1:00 
Airbnb, travel like a human Herald Sun 18 Feb 2015 News 
REPORTS that accommodation website Airbnb is now a $25 billion business have spurred Tourism Accommodation Australia into taking action to try to regulate the booming industry. 
The valuation from business researcher PrivCo , follows phenomenal growth in Airbnb since its San Francisco start-up in 2008. 
The website now has listings in over 34,000 cities and 190 countries, including dozens throughout Australia. 
CREEPED OUT: How things got really weird for Airbnb Booming ... Airbnb’s growth and value compared with other accommodation providers. Source: News Corp Australia 
Sydney has the largest number of Airbnb properties in Australia with an estimated 10,023, followed by Melbourne with 5388, Perth with 1838, Brisbane with 1405, the Gold Coast-Tweed region with 1266 and Adelaide with 766. 
In a series of submissions to State and Federal Governments, TAA seeks to have laws introduced requiring the registration of rooms that are let on a commercial short term basis by individuals. 
The submissions argue that the number of unregulated accommodation providers in Australia has exploded, and a national system is needed to ensure the safety of guests, and the payment of tax on any earnings. Concerned ... TAA chairman Martin Ferguson wants new laws requiring the registration of Airbnb properties. Picture Andrew Taylor Source: News Corp Australia 
TAA Chairman Martin Ferguson said Airbnb had grown at such a rate it now threatened the livelihood of regulated tourism providers. 
“We are not against the ‘sharing’ economy, but we are opposed to the ‘taking’ economy, where unregulated commercial short-term accommodation providers take lots of money without meeting their obligations to guests, the community and the wider economy,” said Mr Ferguson. 
“If there is rampant growth of illegal short-stay commercial accommodation, it will significantly reduce the likelihood of investment in tourist accommodation, which has the potential to be one of the most sustainable generators of future employment in Australia.” Cheap ... the back of a van, which was available for rent on Airbnb at $15 a night. Source: Supplied 
Already a number of local governments are taking action against people who rent out their properties without council approval. 
Hobart City Council has started enforcement proceedings against 27 properties for renting their home to short-term visitors without prior approval. 
Variety ... have bed, will rent. All forms of accommodation are listed with Airbnb. 
Randwick Council in Sydney also takes a stern approach to “unauthorised bed and breakfast businesses” issuing ten-day warning letters, followed by $110,000 fines for noncompliance. 
The City of Sydney Council recently began its own crackdown, threatening $750 fines for properties rented out without approval. 
Mr Ferguson said they believed the best approach was model legislation requiring Airbnb operators to register their properties, to allow better monitoring and management. 
An Airbnb spokesman said hosts were “encouraged to familiarise themselves with locally set regulations, which differed from council to council and even street to street, all over the world”. 
“These laws can be confusing and we're working with policymakers around the world on clear, progressive and fair laws that allow for homesharing,” said the spokesman.
